title: 105_s2495
content: The Act is titled the "Kate Mullany National Historic Site Act" and includes sections on definitions, findings and purposes, establishment of the historic site, acquisition of property, administration of the site, and authorization of appropriations. The Act defines terms such as "historic site," "plan," and "Secretary." The Kate Mullany House in Troy, New York, is a National Historic Landmark with significance in American labor history. Troy played a key role in the collar and cuff industry and early worker organizations. Kate Mullany led the first women's labor union in the city. The city of Troy, New York, led by Irish immigrant Kate Mullany, has formed a partnership with neighboring municipalities to create the Hudson-Mohawk Urban Cultural Park Commission. This area, designated as a heritage area by the State of New York, focuses on industrial development and labor themes. Known as "RiverSpark", this partnership park aims to conserve the area's heritage through intergovernmental and public-private partnerships for preservation, education, recreation, and economic development. The Kate Mullany National Historic Site aims to preserve and interpret the home of Kate Mullany for education and inspiration. It also highlights the connection between immigration and the industrialization of the United States. The Kate Mullany National Historic Site focuses on preserving the home of Kate Mullany and highlighting the connection between immigration and the industrialization of the United States, including Irish immigration, women's history, and worker history. Establishment of Kate Mullany National Historic Site in New York, consisting of Kate Mullany's home on Eighth Street in Troy. The site is approximately .05739 acre in size. Acquisition of property is also addressed. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land and personal property within the boundaries of the historic site for management purposes. Acquisition can be done through donation, purchase, or exchange. The administration of the historic site is also addressed. The Secretary administers the historic site in accordance with applicable laws and may enter into cooperative agreements with various entities to facilitate public understanding and enjoyment of Kate Mullany's life and work through exhibits and activities. The Secretary may display items associated with Kate Mullany for the interpretation of the historic site. A general management plan must be developed within 2 years, including recommendations for regional exhibits through cooperative agreements with entities. The plan for the historic site must be prepared in accordance with the National Park System General Authorities Act and include agreements with various entities. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
